```{r,echo=FALSE}
library(reticulate)
options(scipen=999)
pfix = function(c,d){
    p = paste0("{",c,"}x^{",d,"}",collapse="+")
    p = gsub("x^{0}","",p,fixed=T)
    p = gsub("x^{1}","x",p,fixed=T)
    p = gsub("+{-","-{",p,fixed=T)
    p = gsub("+{1}x","+x",p,fixed=T)
    p = gsub("-{1}x","-x",p,fixed=T)
    p = gsub("{-1}x","-x",p,fixed=T)
    p = gsub("{1}x","x",p,fixed=T)
    return(p)
}
gcd2 <- function(a, b) {
  if (b == 0) a else Recall(b, a %% b)
}
gcd <- function(...) Reduce(gcd2, c(...))

while(T){
    ab = sample(1:10,2)
    a = ab[1]
    b = ab[2]
    if(gcd(a,b)==1){break}
}
A = a^2
B = b^2

ch = c(pfix(c(paste(a),paste(b,"i")),1:0),
       pfix(c(paste(a),paste(-b,"i")),1:0),
       pfix(c(paste(a),paste(b)),1:0),
       pfix(c(paste(a),paste(-b)),1:0)
       )

chall = character()
for(i in 1:4){
    for(j in i:4){
        ij = sample(c(i,j))
        chall = c(chall,paste0("(",ch[ij[1]],")\\cdot(",ch[ij[2]],")",collapse=""))
    }
}

ord = sample(1:10)
al = paste0("* $",chall[ord],"$",collapse="\n")
sol = paste0(1*(ord==2),collapse="")

```


Question
========

Consider the quadratic function, $f(x)$, written in standard form:

$$f(x)~=~`r pfix(c(A,B),c(2,0))`$$

The function $f(x)$ can be rewritten as a product of two linear factors. What are those two linear factors?
